source.460c5a4e:
Definitions of the columns:

age = age of the patient

sex = gender of the patient (male = 1 female = 0)

cp = chest pain, from 0 to 4 -- Value 1: typical angina - Value 2: atypical angina - Value 3: non-anginal pain - Value 4: asymptomatic

trestbps = resting blood pressure on mmHg when getting into the hospital

chol = serum cholestoral in ml/dl

fbs = fasting blood sugar > 120 mg/dl (1 = true; 0 = false)

restecg = resting electrocardiographic results (values 0,1,2)

thalach = maximum heart rate achieved

exang = exercise induced angina (1 = yes; 0 = no)

oldpeak = ST depression induced by exercise relative to rest

slope = the slope of the peak exercise ST segment

ca = number of major vessels (0-3) colored by flourosopy

thal = 3 = normal; 6 = fixed defect; 7 = reversable defect

target = 0 False 1 True for disease
source.328abc7f: Let's check the chest pain distribution between gender
source.d961715a: We have way more men in the dataset
source.3c6da293: Our population varies from 29 to 77 years old
source.236538d0: No null data on the dataset, which is a good thing. Now let's check the type of each column
source.04420bf9: No clear relationship between: age, resting blood pressure, chest pain and gender. On the second row we see a tendency, but it disappears in the other rows.
source.9b70ce32: Spliting chest pain in two main groups: men and women, we see that among each group there are consistent differences. Men tend to have more typical angina.
source.b1ec6f2f: We have 207 men against 96 women in the dataset
source.15f057b8: The age that divides our dataset in 50/50 is 55
source.2d18394c: Women tend to have a narrower age distribution for typical agina and asymptomatic.
source.49d5bc3d: No clear correlation between age, gender, cholesterol and chest pain
